question: Commander Sonak... ! You've received your appointment as Enterprise Science Officer? Why aren't you on board? Here at Starfleet...? The Enterprise is in final preparation to leave dock... Twelve! I'm on my way to a meeting with Admiral Nogura which will not last more than three minutes. Report to me on the Enterprise in one hour. I intend to be there following that meeting. Report to me. One hour!
answer: Admiral, I've been hoping to see you. Maybe you can get through to those thick heads in Starfleet that...

question: Why aren't the Enterprise transporters in operation, Mister Scott?
answer: We're hoping it's only a temporary problem, Admiral...

question: See that it is. Take me over, please.
answer: Admiral, the Enterprise has just finished eighteen months redesign- ing and refitting. She needs testing, a shakedown...

question: Mr. Scott, there's an alien object with unbelievable destructive power less than three days away from this planet... ... the only Starship in interception range is the Enterprise! Ready, or not, she launches in twelve hours!
answer: The crew hasn't had near enough transition time with all the new equipment. And the engines, Admiral

question: Two and a half years as Chief of Starfleet Operations may have made me a little stale, Mr. Scott -- but I wouldn't exactly consider myself 'untried.' They gave her back to me, Scotty.
answer: "Gave' her back, sir...? I doubt it was that easy... But any man who could manage such a feat, I wouldna dare disappoint. She'll launch on time, sir... And she'll be ready. Sir, you'll excuse me...?

question: Admiral Kirk... We're getting a top brass send off...? She'll launch on schedule if we have to tow her out with our bare hands. Right, Scotty?
answer: Will, let's go over here and talk.

question: Let me now when the back-up is in place. All due respect, sir, I hope this isn't a Starfleet pep talk; I'm just too busy.
answer: I'm taking over the Center seat. I'm sorry, Will.

question: You are what...?
answer: I'm replacing you as Captain of the Enterprise. You'll stay aboard as Executive Officer... a temporary grade reduction to Commander.

question: -- You, personally, are assuming command?
answer: Yes.

question: May I ask Why?
answer: My experience -- five years out there dealing with unknowns like this -- my familiarity with the Enterprise, this crew...

question: Admiral, this is an almost totally new enterprise. You don't know her a tenth as well as I do.
answer: That's why you're staying aboard. I'm sorry, Will.

question: No, Admiral. I don't think you are; not one damned bit. I remember when you recommended me for this command. You told me how envious you were, and if only you could find a way to get a starship command again. Well, sir, it looks like you found a way.
answer: Report to the bridge, Commander. Immediately.

question: Maneuvering thrusters, Mister Sulu.
answer: Maneuvering thrusters, sir.

question: Hold station.
answer: Thrusters at station-keeping, sir.

question: Warp Drive as soon as possible, Mr. Scott.
answer: Captain, it was our anti-matter imbalance that created the wormhole in the first place. It will happen again if we don't correct it.

question: That object out there is less than two days from Earth, Mister Scott. We've got to intercept while it still is out there!
answer: Aye, we understand that sir! We're doing our best.

question: Explanation, Mr. Decker
answer: Sir, the Enterprise redesign increases phaser power by channeling it through the main engines. When they went into anti-matter imbalance, the phasers were automatically cut off.

question: Then you acted properly, of course.
answer: Thank you, sir. I'm sorry I embar- rassed you.

question: You saved the ship.
answer: I'm aware of that, sir.

question: Stop competing with me, Decker!
answer: Permission to speak freely, sir?

question: Granted.
answer: Sir, you haven't logged a single star hour in two and a half years. That, plus your unfamiliarity with the ship's design -- in my opinion, sir, seriously jeopardizes our mission.

question: I trust you will... nursemaid me through these difficulties, Mister?
answer: Yes, sir, I'll do that.

question: Was he difficult?
answer: No more than I expected Not as difficult as this. I'm sorry...

question: That you left? or that you didn't say 'goodbye'?
answer: If I'd seen you again, would you have been able to say it?

question: Reporting as ordered, Captain.
answer: Sit down, please.

question: Sir, I would appreciate Dr. McCoy absenting himself from this interview.
answer: I want him here. Sit down! You've reported that you felt strong thought emotions. A group of minds from a space vessel? Could you make out any plan, anything to do with Earth?

question: Negative, Captain. I could sense only what seemed an almost omniscient pattern of perfect logic. I can explain nothing more; I understand nothing more.
answer: Also -- there was nothing in your report about why you're here.

question: That inquiry invades my personal life, Captain.
answer: I inquired about you -- learned you were studying with the Masters...

question: Your deductions do you credit, Doctor... if your puerile curiosity does not. I still contain fragments of my human half.
answer: And whatever you sensed out here....

question: ... is my only hope of accomplishing what the Masters could not.
answer: Let it drop, Bones. You are my Science Officer -- I'll expect an immediate report on anything further you learn or sense from here on.

question: I have accepted service here as a Starfleet officer... sir.
answer: I know this has been painful, Spock. For me too. Thank you. Full mag on viewer! Linguacode?

question: Spock, have you sensed anything else?
answer: The 'puzzlement' I sensed was fleeting... minor... ... as if carrying a sense of our insignificance, Captain.

question: Our... 'insignificance'?
answer: We are obviously confronted by a highly advanced mentality... yet they cannot understand who we are, or what we want.

question: Mr. Decker... ?
answer: I advise caution, Captain; we can't withstand another attack.

question: That thing is twenty hours from Earth. We know nothing about it yet.
answer: That's precisely the point, Captain. We don't know it will do. Moving into the cloud -- at this time, is an unwarranted gamble.

question: How do you define unwarranted, mister?!
answer: You asked my opinion, sir.

question: We're closing in on it rapidly, Captain.
answer: Reduce magnification. Factor 4, Mr. Sulu.

question: We're already two settings below that, sir.
answer: Adjust parallel course, Navigator. Bring us in to one hundred kilometers distance.

question: One hundred kilometers...
answer: Hold relative position here...

question: Have a security team meet me at Deck Four main elevator! Take the conn, Mr. Decker Who is...'V'ger'...? Is V'ger the Captain of the alien vessel? Where is Lt. Ilia? Why does V'ger travel to the third planet of the solar system directly ahead? Find the Creator? What Creator? Whose...!? What does V'ger want of the 'Creator'... ?
answer: Join with the Creator... ? How? Who is the Creator?

question: Who is V'ger?
answer: Doctor, a thorough examination of this probe might provide some insight into those who manufactured it, and how to deal with them.

question: We have just seen that its body duplicates our navigator in precise detail. Suppose that beneath its programming, the real Ilia's memory patterns are duplicated with equal precision.
answer: They had a pattern to follow...

question: ... they may have followed it too precisely.
answer: Ilia's memory, her feelings of loyalty, friendship, obedience... might all be there.

question: Bridge, cancel rescue teams. Spock, what in the hell are you doing out here!
answer: I am seeking answers, Captain.

question: Answers to what, Spock? Our dilemma -- or your personal one?
answer: Captain, I believe there we will find an indication of whoever -- or whatever -- is aboard this vessel... It would appear that the atomic arrays of these crystals store information. A remarkably efficient system.

question: And these 'sensor-swarms' collect that data, carry it here.
answer: New crystals

question: Klingons... our Epsilon 9 station ... and Ilia!! They seem to be more than just images...
answer: Exact patterns. The energy bolt that hit them wasn't simply a weapon -- it dematerialized them, stored them. But why?

question: If this is their ship's data banks, where is the crew? Or is their entire ship automated?
answer: Captain, I do not believe there is a crew -- or that this is a vessel as such. I am almost certain now that all of this is V'ger -- I believe that we are inside a life form, a living machine. I must attempt mindmeld with it, Captain.

question: I saw V'ger's planet
answer: Know what, Spock? What? What should you have known?

question: No meaning... No hope... And, Jim, no answers...! Jim, it's looking for answers itself!
answer: What answers?

question: 'Is this all I am? Is there not more?'
answer: I'll be right there... I need Spock on the bridge. A machine planet...? Sending a machine to Earth looking for its Creator...? 'To find the Creator,' the probe said. Find God...? Mr. Chekov, Commander Decker's present location? I want to make a ship's announcement. But it's to be heard only in Engineering. This is the Captain speaking. It appears that the alien ship... V'ger... is NOT a manned vessel...

question: If V'ger destroys the Enterprise, the information V'ger requires will also be destroyed. Because V'ger is going to destroy all the carbon units on the third planet. The information will not be disclosed. Then V'ger must withdraw its orbiting devices.
answer: Captain, the vessel -- V'ger -- obviously operates from a central brain complex...

question: The orbiting devices would be controlled from the point, then...?
answer: Precisely.

question: Captain, what's the next move?
answer: The question is, Mr. Decker, is there a next move... Resume duty stations, Mr. Decker.

question: All personnel resume stations...!
answer: Well, Mr. Decker, it seems my bluff is being called.

question: I'm afraid our hand is pretty weak, Captain. But it's the only game in town.
answer: Mr. Chekov, when do those devices activate?

question: Mr. Scott... on my next signal.
answer: Captain, the orbital device will not be triggered for twenty-two minutes...

question: The point...
answer: The point is, Captain, twenty-two (ALT.

question: Confirm code and transmitting frequency.
answer: Captain Kirk! The fault is here, sir, not in the transmission. The antenna leads have been disconnected. V'ger never intended to accept a transmitted signal.

question: Capture God! In order to retrieve V'ger's data, the Creator has to physically come here!...
answer: And plug the signal directly into the circuitry at this... ... point here, Captain. It should pick up even a tricorder playback.
